node.text:
Combining passions in Big Sur, California.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
My (car) camping coffee recipe:
* Two (generous) scoops of coffee beans ground for chemex (coffee shops can grind to whatever brewing method you use) - I got this amount by weighing how many scoops I needed for ~50g at home and replicating it here.
* I aim to have my water at 200-205°F (10° or so below boiling)- for this I boiled water in a pot and then transferred it into my little kettle. It worked like a charm!
* Wet the filter, empty the chemex, add in the coffee grounds.
* Pour in enough water that the grounds are all wet, watch it bloom (bubbles should come up) for 30-60 seconds
* Add in the rest of your water. I pull the filter out when the water hits the little bump on the chemex (~650g)
* Pop a stroopwaffle on top and enjoy!
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
How do you like your coffee? Let me know if you have any questions!

node.text:
I used to think that the “better” (read : more experienced) I became at traveling in the alpine the more self reliant I would become and therefore the less gear i would require. Oh how naïve I was. In reality, the inverse has proven to be true. It started with this helmet - I realized that it was not enough to get to the trailhead extra early and scramble only with people I know to yell “rock” conservatively. That wind and animals and the subtle shifting of the earth (not to mention groups ascending during our descent) can all cause rocks to fall - and it was no longer worth the risk. As I sit at my kitchen table this morning slowly unpacking and letting the 50lbs of gear I hauled into the mountains this weekend air out/dry I cant help but think of the days I used to run through avalanche terrain and slide down glaciers without a care in the world. Ignorant bliss and a whole lot of luck I guess.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
These days my legs shake and I need a little self pep talk before stepping into moderate terrain - even with all of the gear and knowledge that the past half decade has provided me. The more time I spend in the mountains the more I want to see and the more terrified I am of them.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
And yes, on hot summer days I will opt to hike in shorts and sports bras (lathered in sunscreen) - but I promise in that backpack of mine resides a handful of layers and everything I need to survive a night stranded in the alpine (and my @garminoutdoor inReach so hopefully I wont need to).

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Andrea Ference on July 15, 2021 tagging @vagabondhearts, and @mikesugianto. May be an image of one or more people and nature.

node.text:
A reminder today that there are so many people from your past who know only a version of you that no longer exists.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
The other day, in the most misogynist and condescending of ways, a distant family member I had all but forgotten referred to me as a princess. It was in response to me correcting their inappropriate behaviour toward a medical professional tasked with my grandmother’s care. And for a fraction of second he made me feel small - and then my blood began to boil and my body tensed and instead of going with my gut instinct to defend myself - I simply left the group chat. There was nothing of value for me in there anyways and his mind was not worth changing. He spoke to me in the way that he would have 25+ years ago, possibly the last time we interacted, when I wore nothing but pink frilly dresses and clung to my daddy’s hand for dear life. But in that quarter century I have changed. He chose a simpler, easier life and while there is nothing wrong with that - I didn’t. I choose the path of most resistance, packed my bags and moved across the country to study politics and neuroscience, regularly carry half my bodyweight in gear and haul it up mountains to spend weeks alone. I have traveled around the world several times over learned new languages, rode camels in Egypt and saw the sun rise over the Taj Mahal in India, I have slept under the stars in the Andes and the Alps and at the bottom of the Grand Canyon. I run marathons and swim with sharks and walk on ice tens of thousands of years old. I have built a business from the ground up… and I have done all of these things and more… on my own.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
I once was a princess, the only girl with too many brothers and maybe just a little bit of a daddy’s girl. But that, my friends, was a long time ago. There will aways be people clinging to past versions of you like a security blanket, they will use it to make you feel small, to control you, to belittle you. Don’t let them. Embrace that you have grown past the person you once were and past the people who refuse to acknowledge and celebrate your progress.

node.text:
With such a short summer up here in Canada my morning routine more often than not goes out the window. So when I am home (or at a home) it is nice to slow it down. Drink a glass of water, carve out time to meditate, make a cup of coffee (preferably drink it surrounded by mountains in a field of daisies as the sun rises) and move my body. What is your ideal morning routine?
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
Wearing:
@sweatybetty Power High-Waisted 7/8 Workout Leggings - they just launched these in a new range of new prints and solid colours (including this Health Green)
@sweatybetty Mindful Seamless Long Sleeve Top

node.text:
Fifteen minutes before these photos were taken I was curled up in a little ball at the base of the dock with all of the down and gore-tex jackets I packed in my backpack piled atop. Trying to convince Oesa to cuddle with me for warmth as I fiddled with the camp stove to make a cup of coffee. The smile in these photos is real - happiness for hot cups of coffee on cool fall mornings and the moment that the first light hit my cheeks - feeling instantly warmer.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
I have been receiving more pushback recently than ever before calling social media, and by extension me as a human, fake. Accusations that backcountry camping photos are roadside or brought in by helicopter(I wish) or photoshopped or some really creative camera angles. These things used to deeply hurt me. These days I do my best to laugh them off and move on with my life. Knowing that hurtful comments and messages in reality have little to do with me. But also serve as a reminder that most everything found online is a shade of grey. The smile and the hot cup of coffee are real but can’t possibly tell the whole story of a headlight lit 12km hike in - the freezing hour waiting for sunlight to flood in or the mid day nap on a rock in the sun while a squirrel rummaged through my snacks. That sometimes sleeping without a rainfly is nice, and other times it just looks nice in a photo - neither of which negate from the camping the evening prior. The infographics and “facts” shared in stores are just a small piece of a bigger puzzle. I implore you to dig deeper, to use critical thinking. But with that - I have felt the internet become a much more hurtful place over the past 18 months. And I don’t blame people. We are, collectively, exhausted and bored and spending far more time inside and online. I guess what I am trying to say is question everything you see online… but before spewing vitriol remember that there is a human reading your words and that sometimes things are fake but other times they may just be a small chapter in a much larger story.

node.text: There is note in my phone titled “sufferfest” - it is shared with @mikesugianto and in its essence - a compilation of unenjoyable things we want to do together. The more time that the note has existed the more outlandish its contents have become. This was the first (and definitely the easiest) of them. With Albertans unable to reserve camping at Berg Lake we decided to catch sunrise is a far less comfortable way. Hitting the trail at 11pm just as the sun was setting, on no sleep (or coffee) we hiked up the 21km just in time to catch first light on Mount Robson. It was much colder than forecasted -  we were tired and hungry but we made it. We stayed for a under an hour, ate a celebratory snack (I took a five minute nap on a bench) and just as the alpenglow began to fade we were back at it, heading down those same 21km. Passing campers emerging from their tents, eating breakfast, sipping coffee as we hopped down the mountain. Making games out of avoiding flooded out trials (or daring one another to run straight through them) and bets about ice cream - we were filled with delirious laughter most of the way out. This was the first adventure of the summer - it was dumb and hard and kind of perfect.

node.text:
I like to think of Tofino as “Canadian California” a much smaller, quite a bit further north (and understandably chiller) version of the golden state. Like SoCal there are expansive beaches that, during winter storms, are filled with surfers bobbing up and down waiting for waves (although fewer bikinis and boards shorts and more full-body wetsuits). The thick rainforest reminiscent of the redwoods perfect for rainy day walks and long trail runs alike and, the town its self, with fresh caught seafood, great coffee, cute boutique hotels like @theshorelinetofino and my favourite burritos in all of Canada - reminds me of so many oceanside towns along the central California coast.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
The restrictions are finally lifting on British Columbia (and hopefully all of North America soon) - which makes now the prefect time to plan a getaway to this little piece of paradise. I wrote a blog post (link in my bio) to help you in your planning with everything you need to know, including:
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
• how to get to Tofino
• where to stay
• what to eat
• the best coffee in town
• hikes and trail runs of every level
• things to do in town
• how to get around
• what to pack for every weather and activity
• & everything you need to know before you go (including transportation, sleeping in your car, camping and beach fires)
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
'𝗦𝗔𝗩𝗘' 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗽𝗼𝘀𝘁 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗽𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴!

node.text:
This was the day after my first real solo backcountry camping trip - and probably five days without a real shower. I had @ryanclennett drop me off at the trailhead (third slide - my first day of solo camping photo) and we made plans to meet back up a few days later. We had no way to communicate (this was pre- @garminoutdoor inReach days for me) and somehow managed to time things just right, arriving at the trailhead within seconds of one another. It poured rain almost the entire time I was away and he was worried that I may have had a miserable trip and so… he came equipped with fresh donuts, just in case. I happily ate the donuts (see second slide) and yammered all about my time alone in the wilderness. Of the momma bear and her two cubs that bathed in a pond that doubled as my drinking water as I sipped my morning coffee. Of the storms that rolled in and out and the German architect that hiked up for lunch one day and we shared a rock to sit on, a few snacks and a handful of stories.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
We drove into town for maybe ten minutes total, I re-supplied, ditched my trash and we were back on our way. Another trailhead, another few nights (and thankfully a dry backup tent). No rain but a lot of wind, some wasted time finding somewhere safe to river cross as the temperature rose and with it a glacial river in our path.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
The end of every summer makes me a little bit sad. That I know that all of the fun I had will never exist in exactly the same way. That people grow up and their priorities change. That my favourite backcountry spots, once reserved for solitude, gain popularity. The landslides and rockfalls block access points or forest fires ravage mountainsides. And so this is my early season reminder to be safe, be responsible… and to take a few minutes to appreciate your “now” because once its gone there is no getting it back.

node.text:
What is your go-to hiking snack?
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
I am always on the hunt for my next favourite snack and when @lairdsuperfood told me about Pili Nuts I was more than intrigued. Unlike anything I have tried before they are grown on trees rooted in volcanic soil in the Philippines and have a rich, buttery taste (with no greasy fingers). For the past few month these powerful little nuts have kept me fueled on every hike and travel day - my biggest snack decision these days is which of their three flavours to choose. #LSFPartner
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
2021.05.07
Big Sur, California, USA

🎥: @mtch3l
 ⠀ ⠀ ⠀
#hiking #snacks #bigsur #california #USA #PiliNuts #reels

node.text:
I have a friend named Tyler, years ago on a hike (third photo) he explained to me that his motivation for taking photos stemmed from a fear of one day losing his memory. The photos he takes are a preemptive attempt to bring him back to those moments in time.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
I don’t know if it will work and I hope he ever has to try. But every so often I look at a photo and think of Tyler and wonder what moment I would be brought back to.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
This one isn’t as pleasant as it looks. I was sick with the flu when we made the hike in, not too bad just shy of 10km with 800m of gain and 300 loss. But with my hip belt pressed against my distended stomach every step felt excruciating. We set up the tent late in the evening and woke up to a sky filled with smoke from nearby forest fires. Our lungs burned as we breathed and we knew it was just the beginning. This first photo I was distracted by a group of young boys, a little overzealous and explicitly not open to help, make wrong decision after wrong decision attempting to gain the ridge above. Nothing dangerous just wasting time and energy on a long day that I don’t think they realized they had ahead of them.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
As mid morning rolled around and we accepted that it would be days or weeks before we saw the sun again we hiked down, made a little ramen and I hopped in the lake - an attempt to fully wake up and shake off any lingering feelings of illness before packing up camp and hiking out.
⠀ ⠀ ⠀
What is your motivation to take photos? I think mine is to share moments. One of my favourite things is seeing photos and hearing stories of generations past.
